text: Depending on the sport, day of week can do weird things too (horse racing on a Monday is arguably a different sport to horse racing on a Saturday in terms of fundamentals and punters betting on it).

text: Interesting stuff, and well done for sharing. I’m curious about your comment on making/taking - I have always assumed there is more value with making (you can see the value priced in), with the risk being you don’t get matched. Is your main risk that you only get matched adversely?

text:
Thanks for sharing! I'm curious of what metrics you look at most as you are deploying live. Of course at the EOD pnl is what matters, but in the shorter term do you have EV metrics that you are closely monitoring?
 And if so, are you willing to share your EV numbers (wrt to bsp or any other way you calculate it)?

text:
<@U012XF5CNPN> - yes, adverse selection is the big problem. No one is forced to take your offers so when you do get matched it's much more likely because you're wrong. In addition to that, making prices on Betfair is a really shit deal:

1. No maker/taker fee structure unlike most (virtually every?) other financial exchanges
2. No Last Look mechanism unlike being a bookmaker/some trading venues
3. No idea who your counterparty is unlike being a bookmaker/some trading venues
I wonder if the big market makers do have one or more of these although I've never heard anything to that effect

elements.text: - yes, adverse selection is the big problem. No one is forced to take your offers so when you do get matched it's much more likely because you're wrong. In addition to that, making prices on Betfair is a really shit deal:
No maker/taker fee structure unlike most (virtually every?) other financial exchanges
No Last Look mechanism unlike being a bookmaker/some trading venues
No idea who your counterparty is unlike being a bookmaker/some trading venues
I wonder if the big market makers do have one or more of these although I've never heard anything to that effect

text: <@U05REBJ21EC> backtest equity curve all day long, Not sure if this is galaxy brain or smooth brain thinking. I do think it's getting me into some overfitting trouble with some of these strategies so I need to up my crossvalidation game. Very roughly I would say the _gross_ EROI for these strategies is between 5% and 10% although typically I would be happy looking for stuff that makes 1%

text:
Aside from the filtering <@UBS7QANF3> mentions I'd rather modify the algo than filter. With the right coefficients the impact of any given parameter can vary over its range. Eg if you want to exclude higher prices then rather having a strict cutoff I'd describe that as a polynomial such that low prices produce a larger signal than high ones.  Repeat similarly for all parameters and when combined the filtering becomes formulaic and based on far more factors than simple if < or >.  It's not filtered, it just doesn't create a signal large enough, but equally could result in an order if another factors had very strong signals although the price element of the signal generated was low.  

It's illogical to think that any parameter has a cliff edge, and if the impact doesn't vary over the range then why have it in the algo, so what's left is a way to calculate it's impact and for most situations I find a poly curve can describe that quite well. My only filter is the one that tests the signal threshold.

elements.text: Aside from the filtering

mentions I'd rather modify the algo than filter. With the right coefficients the impact of any given parameter can vary over its range. Eg if you want to exclude higher prices then rather having a strict cutoff I'd describe that as a polynomial such that low prices produce a larger signal than high ones.  Repeat similarly for all parameters and when combined the filtering becomes formulaic and based on far more factors than simple if < or >.  It's not filtered, it just doesn't create a signal large enough, but equally could result in an order if another factors had very strong signals although the price element of the signal generated was low.  

It's illogical to think that any parameter has a cliff edge, and if the impact doesn't vary over the range then why have it in the algo, so what's left is a way to calculate it's impact and for most situations I find a poly curve can describe that quite well. My only filter is the one that tests the signal threshold.

text:
I can think of some cliff edges that are worth thinking about when sizing: to deal with minimum stake/payout/liability pieces (which I do plenty of as I'm market making, but might just be me leaking alpha here). I stumbled into a three figure mistake the other week by allowing a MARKET_ON_CLOSE to actually lapse because parts of the order chipped away dropping the liability < £10... and even if I coded up to spot that and move it to PERSIST, it often never matched... and then left me exposed elsewhere... repeat that enough and it doesn't half add up :money_with_wings:

I mention it in this context because let's suppose you are sizing to a payout, but the minimum liability (not payout), to enter BSP auction is £10. If you're near minimums for either (say £10), you've effectively built a strategy around a price inflection point. £20 payout at 2.0 has a £10 liability so if you hedge to auction that will work :white_check_mark: . At 1.99 it doesn't, and will LAPSE :no_entry: So, there you go, an actual cliff edge based on a price.

I mention it in this context because let's suppose you are sizing to a payout, but the minimum liability (not payout), to enter BSP auction is £10. If you're near minimums for either (say £10), you've effectively built a strategy around a price inflection point. £20 payout at 2.0 has a £10 liability so if you hedge to auction that will work
. At 1.99 it doesn't, and will LAPSE
So, there you go, an actual cliff edge based on a price.

text: I'd be reluctant to call that a filter <@U012XF5CNPN>, more a constraint or feature :joy:.    I've had that bsp min dilema, i ended up saying if stake > min/2 then do the min, otherwise 0. Ie I'm nearer to doing it than not and 9.99 isn't going to be a deal breaker. Yes it just moves the constraint but sometimes I'll make do with Duck tape rather than an invisible mend.

text:
<@U0128E7BEHW> - assume you mean (mean daily pnl / std daily pnl) * sqrt(365)?

• Strategy0: 1.63. However, it looks to me that the strategy only _started_ working in 2021. Sharpe ratio since 2021 is 2.47
• Strategy1 Pre-event: 2.97
• Strategy1 In-play: 3.89
• Strategy2: 3.05
My guess for undisclosed reasons is Strategy0 has the lowest capacity followed by Strategy2 followed by Strategy1
